comment.narrative:
Output 1: Co-existence between farmers, pastoralists and returnee communities enhanced; Targets: 1.1 At least 250 youth peace ambassadors trained 1.2 9 community events and forums organized 1.3 9 farm protection committees in place
Output 2: Mechanisms for resolution of land conflicts between returnees, nomads reduced in place and functional Targets: 2.1 At least 5 arbitrations supported 2.2 1 regional conference held
Output 3: Conflict and competition over natural resources and livelihood reduced strategies through productive infrastructure and job creation. Targets: 3.1. Recruit 4RRR/DS Coordinators and second them to State Return Commissions 3.2. Organize regular RRR/DS Coordination meetings in North, South, West and East Darfur States 3.3. Organize regular inter-agency verification and assessment missions to return areas
Output 4: Access to micro-finance enhanced for improved livelihoods among vulnerable IDP and returnee producers, especially vulnerable women
4.1. 4 key training workshops on micro-enterprise development; 4.2. 10 voluntary savings and lending associations established 4.3. Business start-up grants to returnee, IDP, youth and women entrepreneurs through enterprise challenges 4.4. Training and material support to the Darfur microfinance APEX and MFIs at Darfur five states.
Output 5: Support to stabilization of local communities through community empowerment and creation of livelihood activities for vulnerable groups, particularly at-risk youth Targets 5.1 4 workshops organized and number of people trained 5.2 500 youth employed

1. Needs assessments had been conducted for the target communities at 10 localities has been completed in partnership with government institutions and IPs. This helped to align targeted activities with needs on the ground. 1.1 Selection of Youth Peace Ambassadors in 9 targeted localities to promote Peace and Social Cohesion in nine targeted localities of El Geneina Rural, Kutum, Assalaya, Ed Daein, Ed Al Fursan, Tawila, Dar-es-Salam, Golo and Nertiti was completed. 1.2 Community trust and confidence activities comprising sports, drama, dialogue forums and music events, implemented in 14 areas in Darfur states in conjunction with UNAMID/UNPOL. Namely in Tawila, Sortony, Kabkabiyia, Menawashi, Khor Abeche, Nertiti, Golo, Kass, Shangli Tobai, Saraf Omera, Zalengi, Kalama, Kutum and Mershing. These events attended by 1,545 people of whom 959 males and 586 females. 1.3 Twelve Farm Protection committee (FPCs) have been formed and received training at Ed Alfursan, Assalaya, Ed Deain, El Fasher, El Kuma, Gereida, Kutum, El geneina and Beida localities. A total of 226 participants were trained of whom 6% were women. 1.3.1 A number of 33 mobile phone kits had been distributed to FPCs at the five states to enable reporting incidents in real time.
2. Discussions were held with local authorities with a view to monitoring, assessing, and supporting Land Conflict Arbitration and Management Committees in 10 major return areas and migratory routes. Two research studies were done in 17 Return and Host community locations to identify factors causing conflicts over land. 2.1 Based on the causes of conflicts identified, 10 dialogue meetings were organized drawing 177 participants (104 males and 73 females) in four sessions in North Darfur state, and 220 participants (173 males and 47 females) in six session in South Darfur state. 2.1.1 Training on conflict arbitration had been done for 173 active members including women in North and South Darfur states. 2.1.2 Arbitration committees were established at 14 return villages (10 in South Darfur and 4 in North Darfur states) to address land conflicts in their respective areas. 2.1.3 Four land information data centres have been activated at the departments of Agriculture and Animal Resources and operated by government staff. 2.1.4 Two workshops were conducted in land conflict resolution and information management benefiting 68 government staff and native administration at North and South Darfur states.
3.1 The UNDP recruited 4 RRR coordinators and deployed in 2020 and support the UNCT, AHCT and VRRC in coordinating RRR and durable solutions processes at Darfur and Khartoum levels. 3.2 UNDP provided equipment and material for VRRC and other state institution to boost their capacity to coordinate verification and assessment missions and information management. 3.3.1 UNDP led 6 verification missions at North, South, East and West Darfur missions in partnership with government institutions and other international agencies. 3.3.2 UNDP with El Fashir University Centre for Peace and Development to assess key institutions capacity related to durable solutions in the four states to identify potential hosts for land information centres. 3.4 The UNDP has successfully rehabilitated and activated Nertiti Nursery including installation of water tank, improving the Solar System and providing seeds and rehabilitating the seedbeds shelter and constructing a fence. Also, trained 20 farmers as ToTs who trained 200 farmers on Improved Technology packages for citrus production. 3.5 The project has rehabilitated Nertiti Community Training Centre with ceramic floors and fully painted out and a generator for electricity installed at the centre. Also, the centre had been fenced and provided two rooms for guards and a store. The centre had been equipped with 10 Desktops and 10 sewing machines for training more than 400 youth of whom 40% are women.
4.1 A number of 6 workshops have been organized for entrepreneurships on micro-enterprise development skills and practice of small business management in East, South, North and West Darfur states. 4.2 UNDP established 34 Saving and Lending Associations with membership 1,700 of whom 80% are women at East, South and Central Darfur states. 4.3 Some 17 entrepreneurs were selected through challenge competition and supported with start-up grants for grinding machines and five restaurants. 12 youth supported with grants for mobile solar chargers, and eight women teamakers supported with kits for expanding their business. 4.4 One data server had been procured and installed at the GDMFA and 15 desktops and 6 printers to MFIs affiliated with the Apex to support microfinance in Darfur five states.
5. Three assessment missions were conducted at the community level in coordination with government partners. The assessment focused on institutions working on durable solutions process mainly return and re-integration. The assessment showed myriad challenges affecting productivity in the institutions. Four key infrastructure projects have been completed and handed over to the communities: 5.1 The UNDP has completed the construction of a Health Vaccination Centre in Turra. The centre equipped with a refrigerator operated by Solar system. The centre would serve 2,300 of whom 1000 males and 1,300 females. 5.2 A water yard has been provided in Al Heleila at Darelsalm locality which benefits 4000 individuals including three communities in the surrounding area as well to animals of nomads passing by the nearby cattle route. 5.3 The project rehabilitated one water yard at Taufaya at Milet locality. The project serves 4000 individuals, 1600 males and 2400 females. Also, the yard provide water for livestock and hence reduced tension and promoted peaceful co-existence. 5.4 The project supported Turra community to rehabilitate two water handpumps to improve availability and access to potable water for human and livestock. The water yard serves more than 3000 individuals of whom 500 men and 2500 women.

Output 3: Conflict and competition over natural resources and livelihood reduced strategies through productive infrastructure and job creation.
Targets: 3.1. One regional conference on land management with emphasis on mediation and arbitration in El Fasher.
3.2 Rehabilitation of water dam in Nertiti

3.1 Through partnership with the Peace and Development at El Fasher University, a peace conference was held in El Fasher with 27 participants (17 men and 10 women) drawen from different localities.
3.2 The UNDP has completed the rehabilitation of Nertiti Dam. The work included de-silting constructing the retaining wall and maintenance of the spillway, rehabilitation of the sluice gates. Also, the UNDP provided anumal drinking toughs and fencing the water distribution point. The capacity of the Water User Committee was strengthened and community meetings were organized to discuss and agree on the sustainability of this water system.
